Lawrence,
Thank you. Now I am told by her daughters, the one with the autistic child, that her mother (my client) is no longer able to take care of her affairs. My client sent me an email that her daughter is taking care of her and to communicate through her. Too weird that last year I did not get any sense of this when the story broke.

Sent: Friday, October 31, 2025 1:47:59 PM
Subject: Re:[lawnet] I didn't want to use Renbaum as AME, situation required it - now what?
List: lawnet Sent By: [ mailto:iodlaw@sbcglobal.net ' Lawrence R. Whiting ]
[ mailto:iodlaw@sbcglobal.net?subject=Re%3A%20I%20didn%27t%20want%20to%20use%20Renbaum%20as%20AME%2C%20situation%20required%20it%20-%20now%20what%3F ' Reply To Sender ]
[ mailto:lawnet@lawnet.caaa.org?subject=Re%3A%20I%20didn%27t%20want%20to%20use%20Renbaum%20as%20AME%2C%20situation%20required%20it%20-%20now%20what%3F ' Reply To List ]
[ http://www.caaa.org/index.cfm?pg=search ' Search ]
[ http://www.caaa.org/index.cfm?pg=listviewer&lsAction=listSettings ' Settings ]
Hollie, I see two issues here.
First, is the effect of Rembaum's reports on range of motion. He is giving a legal conclusion. His conclusions should be disregarded. The conclusions are clearly contrary to the AMA guides. On the other hand, I see no benefit to either you or the client by getting another doctor's opinion. I would use this argument to whatever extent you can get the DA to agree toward settlement.
Secondly, to what extent is the DA aware of your applicants lies and overpayments? I'm assuming they don't know or that would have been part of your presentation. You cannot take this case to trial. You would be compounding or, at least condoning, a criminal act.
I would recommend you getting the best settlement you can get and inform your client that you will either settle her case on that amount or you will recuse yourself from the case and file a lien for fees. (Whatever you can get her is more than she deserves.)
If the judge on the case won't let you out I would recommend going to the PJ and, without disclosing facts, indicate why you must recuse yourself. (Your Honor, there are reasons that I cannot disclose that justify my recusal.)
If that becomes a problem, check with the Bar Association for their insight.
Hopefully, this will free up more time for you and your legitimate clients.
-----Original Message-----
From: Hollie@TCLC.org
Sent: October 31, 2025 12:48:00 PM
To: lawnet@lists.trialsmith.com
Subject: I didn't want to use Renbaum as AME, situation required it - now what?
I didn't want to use Renbaum as AME, situation required it - now what?
This is on my client who lied to my VE, Def's VE and PQME stating she was unable to work and had not worked since retiring in 2021, when, in fact, she was working as a Respite Worker for her grandson who is autistic. A Respite Worker takes over when the primary caregiver can't take caregiving anymore. She thought she was being so clever to lie to everyone and get paid for taking care of her grandson. So, in lieu of falling on my sword, DA and I agreed to Renbaum as AME.
I had written previously when Renbaum's report came out and he had apportioned all ortho body parts inured as 40% non-industrial without explaining "how" or "why", what should I do, challenge his apportionment? Get a better explanation? Or ignore it? Response was ignore it and get out of the liar's case ASAP. But I struck with it.
So. Renbaum had made a few other glaring "situations" in his report that needed fixing. A urologist PQME had assigned 5% WPI for incontinence caused by C-spine post-op pathology, original PQME and Urology PQME said to add the Uro PD percentage to the overall ortho percentage per Kite . So now there's Vigil . I asked Renbaum to comment on combining Uro PD percentage to ortho percetage. His response - get a new Urology QME.
IW had an anterior cervical diskectomy and fusion C4-5, C5-6 on March 19, 2018. PQME found markedly abnormal (restricted) ROM at re-exam in May 2021 Renbaum found range of motion was "full" (he did state the degrees with the normals and they were all normal). I asked him if he used an inclinometer or a goniometer to measure the range of motion and could he please explain how IW rehabilitated her cervical spine range of motion from significantly reduced in May 2021 to full by February of 2025? Renbaum answered (this is verbatim), " I do not think rating should be provided for range of motion, as in my opinion it is a very unreliable determinate of the level of impairment." Renbaum did not even answer my questions about inclinometer/goniometer and how IW rehabilitated her neck. He just said that irrespective of an employee's ROM, he would not consider ROM in his rating and he would never rate a spine using the ROM method.
In my view, Renbaum's response that he cannot rely on ROM to determine WPI and he doesn't believe in the ROM rating method is disqualifying. Should I challenge his qualifications? Get a better explanation of his opinion on ROM methodology? Or ignore it?
If the response is to ignore it and get out of the liar's case ASAP, any Judge who sees this case and reads Renbaum's reports will think I am a lousy, uneducated buffoon who doesn't know the first thing about WC.
Hollie Rutkowski, RN, JD, MBA, Esq.
[ https://the-compensation-law-center.business.site/ ' The Compensation Law Center ]
Sacramento, CA 95834
T:916.974.0424
F:916.974.0428

subject: Re: Deposition Question: Why did you get an attorney, and how did you find your attorney.
body: Please see attached from Google Ai.  I don't recommend blindly following Ai.  But in this case,  I believe it's conclusions are accurate. What are some recent California cases discussing attorney referrals to doctors in depositions?   What are the limits on discovering lawyer-doctor relationships?   What communication with the client is protected by attorney-client privilege in CA depositions?

I've heard DA ask my clients this question during depositions and it is always met with an immediate objection, calls for attorney-client priviledged information- like the other commentors, I've never received a petition to compel applicant answer that atty-client priviledged information.
-----Original Message-----

<mailto:acsillaglaw@gmail.com?subject=Re%3A%20%5Blawnet%5D%20Deposition%20Question%3A%20Why%20did%20you%20get%20an%20attorney%2C%20and%20how%20did%20you%20find%20your%20attorney.> Reply To Sender
<mailto:lawnet@lawnet.caaa.org?subject=Re%3A%20%5Blawnet%5D%20Deposition%20Question%3A%20Why%20did%20you%20get%20an%20attorney%2C%20and%20how%20did%20you%20find%20your%20attorney.> Reply To List
<http://www.caaa.org/index.cfm?pg=search> Search
<http://www.caaa.org/index.cfm?pg=listviewer&lsAction=listSettings> Settings
Edward,
I am trying to wrap my brain around how on this earth or any other planet in the solar system is this relevant to move the needle forward for either side?
Not only does it violate the attorney client privilege, but has no relevance to anything other than a fishing expedition hoping to get some ridiculous response to use against the applicant.
In the personal injury arena, we occasionally get these types of ridiculous questions which are met with an objection based on attorney client privilege.
Never has any DA filed a motion to compel. It is also addressed in motions in limine.
Yes, I would greatly appreciate a copy of the DA's petition and your response and please let us know the outcome.
I would be shocked if any judge ordered the applicant to respond to this nonsense.
What a colossal waste of time.
Art
Arthur Csillag, Esq.
<mailto:ascsillaglaw@gmail.com> acsillaglaw@gmail.com
